"We think teaching is an important occupation in society today . . . we try to give people
a dignified way to get into it."—
John Walton
In May, 1957, the Fund for the
Advancement of Education under
the Ford Foundation awarded
nearly $300,000 to Johns Hopkins
for the establishment of an experimental program directed toward the training of secondary
school teachers.
This fifth year study in teacher education has given rise to the
Master of Arts in Teaching program at Hopkins, and after nine
years Dr. John Walton, chairman
of the Education Department
and director of the MAT, feels
it can be called a success.
Quality Over Quantity
Thomas McDaniel, assistant
director, said in a recent interview, "We don't intend to make
a great dent in the teacher
shortage, but we hope to get
quality in a few."

Many former MAT students
have already distinguished themselves in the teaching field. Recent graduates• of the program .
include the administrative assistant to the
Montgomery
County school superintendent,
the author of a high school text
in chemistry, and two assistant
deans at Amherst and at William
and Mary. Dr. Walton feels that
this kind of work "appeals to
bright people who want to be
active in some kind of social service."
Walton Directs
John Walton was born November 17, 1910, in Fleming County,
Kentucky. He obtained the A.B.
degree from Transylvania College in Lexington and his M.A.
in Classics from the University
of Kentucky.
After serving as a special agent
with the U. S. Army CounterIntelligence Corps during the
war, he pursued graduate studies
at Hopkins until 1950 when he
received a Ph.D. in Education.
Dr. Walton has been the director
of MAT since its conception and
chairman of the Department of
Education since 1960. Last summer he was on the faculty as
a
visiting professor with the
University of California at Santa
Bailpara.
Author
Dr. Walton has authorized
numerous articles and several
books on the subject of education. His books include John Filson of Kentucky, Administrati
on
and Policy-Making in Educat
ion,
and Toward Better Teachi
ng in
the Secondary Schools,
which is
now in the process of
being published. He also contributes to
the
Harvard Educational Review
and
co-edited The Discipline
of Edn•
cation.

Thomas McDaniel, Dr. Walton's assistant and the man
that
"keeps the program going,
" received his B.A. from Hampt
on
Sydney College. Besides
being a
graduate MAT himself, he is
also
married to a former MAT
student. In addition to his
present
duties, he is now studyi
ng for
his doctorate.
Fellowships Awarded
After the MAT system surviv
ed
Its first three years, the
Ford
Foundation, in 1960, donate
d
$700,000 to continue the progra
m
for seven more. This year
the
U. S. Office of Education,
under
the National Education
Act, has
awarded 24 fellowships to
Hopkins to be used by
prospective
MAT's.
Dr. Walton stressed that
this
number is greater than
that
given to any other school
with
the exception of Teacher's
College and the University of
Chicago, both of which have
undergraduate Schools of Education.
When the program began,
there were 28 students.
Today
there are 78, with backgr
ounds
ranging from physics to history
.
Teachers Trained
In general, MAT students
are
graduates of liberal arts college
s
and have had no formal
training in teaching. They must
be
interested in secondary teachi
ng
as a career and must be
prepared to do graduate work in
the
subject they plan to teach.
In
addition to their studies, they
also serve a semester "inter
nship" as instructors in Baltim
ore
area schools.
Dr. Walton emphasizes that
during this segment of their
training MAT's are not so-called
"student teachers" but actually
in charge of their own classes.
He believes that the great success of the "internship" idea is
primarily due the cooperation of
the school system. While the

Folk singing returns to Hopkins tonight with the opening

names of those students who
they feel are capable of becoming outstanding college teachers
to the Campus Representative
of the Woodrow Wilson National
Fellowship Foundation.

seminary intern, stated that
RATT will be open every Friday
and Saturday night, except during Big- Weekends. He added
that plans are being made to
hold poetry and play reading
sessions as well as folk singing.

Applications are now being accepted from interested juniors
and seniors for membership in
Pi Sigma Alpha, the national
political science honor society.
Applicants are required to have
at least ten credits in political
science with a cumulative average in these courses of at least
a B.
Qualified students should submit a list of their courses and
grades to Pablo Drobny, Gilman
Box 144.

New Concert Series
KYung Wha Chung, renowned
classical soloist, will open the
first of a series of concerts
Thursday, October 13 at the
Lyric theatre. This series of
eight concerts, running until
May 10, will feature the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and
such artists as Andres Segovia
and Van Cliburn.
All performances will be on
Thursday evenings and seven will
feature pre-concert lectures. A
number of the rehearsals will be
Open free to the public.
Student subscriptions to the
series are available for eight dollars at the public relations office in Shriver Hall basement
until October twelfth.

Selective Service
Applications for the November
18 and 19 administrations of the
College Qualification Test are
now available at all local Selective Service Board offices. Interested students should pick up an
application card and bulletin as
soon as possible.
Deadline for these two dates
Is midnight, October 21. Early
registration will enable the Testing Service to provide the student with his choice of test center and date.

Moving your body around
is highly inefficient.
If communications were perfect,
you would never have to.
Of course, you would still
have to get exercise.
But that's your problem.
We want to make it easier for you
to contact people, learn,
get information, attend lectures,
and hold meetings.

We developed Picturephone*

service so you can see as well as talk
when you call. And be seen, too.
We introduced Tele-Lecture service
(two-way amplified phone calls)
to let you hear lecturers
in distant locations. And so you
could ask them questions
no matter how far away they were.
Right now, many students can dial
from their dormitories to a
language lab. Soon a student
will be able to dial into a
computer thousands of miles away
to get information for his courses.

Depending on the nature
of the information, he might get
his answer back audibly,
printed on a teletypewriter,
as a video image,
or a facsimile print.
Some of these services
are available now.
Others are being tested.
For the next week or so,
better get a move on.

Drop Date
We view with alarm the callous decision of the
Committee on Undergraduate Standing to move the drop
date a full six weeks forward on the semester calendar.
In doing so, the Administration displays an appalling lack of sympathy and a desperate misunderstanding
of what it means to attend this University as an Undergraduate.
We as Undergraduates are aware that our University functions primarily as a Graduate institution. We
will not dispute the obvious fact that a large measure of
what makes the Undergraduate school unique is the attitudes that are transmitted from the Graduate division.
Nevertheless, it is vital that the Administration
make some distinctions between its student bodies. At
the most basic level, the Administration must realize
that most concerns to which Undergraduates direct themselves are extra-academic. Therefore it is imperative
ihat we balance academic efficiency with the maintenance
of a psychological climate conducive to learning.
It is axiomatic that any University offer its students
flexibility. Before effecting the current system, Hopkins
not only offered flexibility but a system of options whereby a student was permitted to "give up" without incurring punishment. He was permitted to experience
tacit rather than actual failure and thus was permitted
to learn something from the experience.
"Nothing," Bob Dylan once said "succeeds like
failure." It is important that the Administration realize
that it is dealing with people. People only fail when
they are trapped without the opportunity to change their
minds. Failure only leads to failure. If it is the Administration's intention to reduce the size of the Undergraduate student body, then it has undertaken a masterful plan.
But if it believes that we, as prospective real people,
stand to learn as much from failure as success, it will
reverse its present policy before it does irreparable harm
to even one student.

Fraternities Rushed
While the News-Letter hardly sympathizes with
George P. Mahoney's contention that "A man's home is
his castle," we nevertheless are becoming convinced that
a Hopkins man's apartment or fraternity house, if located southeast of the campus, must, of necessity, be a
fortress.
For years now, it has been the summer pastime
for neighborhood toughs to ransack and loot fraternity
houses, with little recource available to the agrieved
brothers. During the school year, the local billies have
similarly shown little reluctance to enter the residences
of Hopkins students, peacefully or otherwise.
Last year, a gang invaded the apartment of four
Hopkins men near 27th and St. Paul Streets, and were
repelled only when confronted with a shotgun. The knifewielding incident at 29th and Calvert last Friday night
is another case in point. And during the rush season,
every fraternity house at one time or another is visited
by local youths who inevitably get drunk and obstinately
refuse to leave quietly.
The University administration, although intensely
mindful of retaining a favorable Hopkins public image,
has still gone to considerable lengths to give fraternities
and individuals the freedom they so greatly desire, especially in the matter of drinking. It has attempted, with
occasional success, to have the Baltimore police adopt
this outlook, also. Having encouraged the local constabulary to look the other way in one matter, the fraternities now register their anger and amazement when
the police hesitate to exert themselves to the utmost to
curtail the activities of the neighborhood juvenile delinquents.
The problem is compounded by the city's notorious lack of police personnel, the inability of the average
Baltimore cop to recognize that two wrongs don't make
a right, and the fact that the many Hopkins people not
in fraternities, but residing in the area, are victims of
an antagonistic police attiude of whose creation they had
no part.
We hope that, when the I.F.C. president meets
with a representative of the Baltimore police next week,
these problems will be frankly discussed and that some
adequate solution can be achieved.

THE THIRTY NINE STEPS points to offset the sevl

must remember the difficulties
faced by an administration that
must please diverse elements in
our society. Yet there are points
when petty disadvantages turn
into grievous and harmful problems, When this point is reached, it is the duty of the members
of the community to unite in an
effort to alleviate the burden
placed upon them. I firmly believe that the problem and
burden which confront both our
sense of justice and our pocketbooks, the inadequacy of the
Johns Hopkins Bookstore, must
now be faced in this spirit.
Every person connected academically with our university is
personally touched by this problem. In my mind it is twofold:
first, there is an inadequacy in
space, service, and atmosphere
which Makes it distasteful to
even enter the bookstore; and
secondly, there is an exorbitant
profit made on each and every
book and off of each and every
purchaser.
We have been told that the
crowded conditions will be alleviated when the renovation of
Gilman Hall is complete (although one professor makes the
point that\he hardly sees where
the bookstore will have room to
expand what with all they plan
to put in the building). Yet this
is but a partial solution. Will we
still have to stand in line for
forty minutes only to find that
the essential book has not arrived? Will we still have to
search painfully for an object
that is hidden in some obscure
corner? What atmosphere will
be present? Perhaps the answers
to some of these questions could
be found in a summer mailing of
booklists so that students could
buy elsewhere or bring books from

home, in a lounging area where
purchasers could sit and browse,
in self-service shelves for textbooks, or in the selling of cultural objects such as prints and.
records.
If these "aesthetic" issues
seem essential, think for a moment about the economic concerns. A rumor (supposedly SUb—
stantiated by the report of the
Long Range Planning Committee) claims that the bookstore's
yearly profit can be approximated at $25,000 which is then
supposedly directed to some obscure or abstract use which helps
the student body. It would seem
to me that some explanation on
the part of the administration is
required. But also something
further. Why cannot our bookstore be run with our economic
comfort in mind? Why must we
pay list prices and receive inadequate service while students
at other top universities (undet.
a co-operative or discount program) pay decidedly less?
I believe that these questions
can be answered this year, but
it will take a united and concerted effort on the part of the
undergraduates, the graduates,
the evening students, and the
faculty. If their efforts be chanthrough a dedicated
nelled
Student Council. I believe we
will find success. And this success will be only the beginning.
Soon the administration will
learn that we speak with a constructive and responsible voice,
and then our other desires will
be acted upon—improved food, a
Student Union, etc. It is now
that we must act—to make the
bookstore an instrument of
academic pursuit and not one of
economic chicanery.
David M. Punk

Students Recruited
At present Hopkins is rather
unique in its teaching degree
system; there are only about
twenty other schools in the
country that offer such instruction, among them Brown, U. of
Chicago, and Duke.
The MAT students come from
colleges located in every section
of the country. As a result of an
efficient publicity campaign, Dr.
Walton states that his office receives around 500 completed applications per year and' thousands of inquiries. "We try to
get a geographical spread," he
maintains. Fewer than 10% of
the MAT's come from Balitmore,
while over 25% remain here to
teach. In this sense Dr. Walton
feels that his department makes
a definite contribution to the
local community.

With the MAT program Dr.
Walton and his staff hope to
change the second rate status
teachers occupy in the educated
community. They intend to show

to raise the quality of the other
schools — the ones that produce
the great majority of our teachers.
As Dr. Walton said, "We wis1
to place teaching on a level that
gives it more prestige, more respect."

By DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN
Robert C. Weaver, Secretary
of Housing and Redevelopment
will give the Albert and Gloria
Lion Lecture on Sunday, October
23, at 4 p.m. in Shriver Hall.

Rudolph Serkin, one of the
vvorld's most eminent pianists,
Will perform in Shriver Hall this
Sunday night at 8:30 p.m. with
violinist Pina Carmirelli. The
two will play the Beethoven
Piano and violin sonatas.
Educated under Arnold
Schoenberg, Rudolf Serkin has
been recognized as one of the
world's finest Beethoven interMeters. As both founder and director of the Marlboro Music
School, to which the proceeds
from this Sunday's concert will
go, he has marked himself as one
of the most generous of contemporary artists. His great contribution to America's cultural life
was recognized in 1963 when
President Kennedy awarded him
the Medal for Freedom.

the late Sunday night hours. It was not known whether the act
had some hidden symbolism pertaining to the Dean's fetishes.

Audiences must realize, for instance, that art is not life.
Though it may closely resemble
it, there are still certain conventions in art which must be
accepted, although such conventions do not exist in life. An example of this would be the scene
from The Umbrellas of Cherbourg where the scenery moves
behind the boy and girl who are
singing a love duet and are obviously not walking. The viewer's
concentration should naturally
be on the couple held in our
vision as they experience and
express their love and anguish.
The moving scenery, caught by
peripheral vision, should give the
illusion of their motion in space.

arising from the new date; but
he promises that the administration intends to maintain an open
mind to all requests for withdrawals after the October 26
deadline.
If a student on academic probation wishes to drop a course at
any time, the drop must be approved by both his adviser and
the Dean if the drop will leave
a program of less than 15 credits for the semester, or may
cause a delay in graduation.

The appearance of Senator
Mansfield brings the Vietnam
war to the forefront once again.
The Senator has been outspoken
in his call for restraint in
the
management of the war.
Vice-President Humphrey was
scheduled to speak at Hopkins
as a part of the 50th anniversary celebration of the School
of
Hygiene and Public Health at
Johns Hopkins. Mr. Humphrey,
however, found it necessary to
cancel his appearance. Mr.
Edward Golden, new head of the
Special Events Committee stated
that the Vice-President's original
committment was only tentative.

Fan Fare

(Continued trom Page 10)

By STEVE PUTNAMIt was a clutch pass that gained the Jays a tie last Saturday,
but to the fans in the rain it
seemed like a victory. Such was
the just reward received by our
hard-core rooters who survived
the afternoon's downpour. Certainly the Jay football team can
not claim as many fans as the
Metz, but in quality and persistence, our fan is comparable
if not superior.
It had to be one of the more
thrilling moments in the history
of Homewood Field, as Phil Parthmore directed a sensational
last minute drive to stave off
defeat. For the Jays it was the
first time in iive years that they
did not lose an opener, and as
for F&M—they went back home
wondering about the remaining
season.
Ursinus Upset
Tomorrow we take on a tough
Ursinus ball club which also tied
last week, playing a scoreless
game with Muhlenburg. Ursinus
IS considered tough because they
have nineteen returning lettermen, including all of their eleven
offensive starters. Last year this
same basic team beat F&M 35-

13. The Jays' line will be outweighed on the average by fifteen pounds per man, but again
there is not complete cause for
despair. No serious injuries were
sustained last week by our magic
"double dozen," and hopefully
with a little luck and support
the team can pull an upset.
Directions
Question three of course is —
who and where is Ursinus? Take
95 north of Maryland State, and
exit at Wilmington, Delaware.
Pick up route 202 and go up to
route 29 around West Chester.
Battle along through construction until you see signs to Collegeville. (Don't be alarmed if
the Pennsylvania
border is
crossed). The Ursinus campus is
located just north of this quaint
Pennsylvania town.
After the game, you might
want to stop at the famous
Smorgasbord restaurant in Collegeville where three dollars
gains you access to all you can
eat. In any event, the Jays need
all the fans they can get for this
tough battle. If they win this
game the prospect of going undefeated becomes almost conceivable.

30 Frosh Gridders
Kick Off Practice
By JEFF LAUREN
The freshmen football team
opened practice last week with
thirty men on Coach Bob Scott's
roster.
Since the young Blue- Jays
have worked out for such a short
time, Scott hesitated to make a
forecast for the '66 season. Only
about half the team has experi.ence.
The team as a whole does not
have the strength or experience
Of the last few Hopkin's frosh
teams. The combined record for
the past two years for freshmen
football is 6-1. It will be an extremely difficult task for this
Year's group to do as well, but
Scott feels that they have the
Potential to offer a good, representative showing.
The coach and his staff will
have a better idea of their team's
strengths and weaknesses when
Harford Junior College comes to
Homewood this Friday afternoon.
Even though Harford has played
a game already and Hopkins has
Only been in pads for a week, the
scrimage will give the coaches
and players a basis from which
to work.

a great dent in the teacher
shortage, but we hope to get

Walton Directs
John Walton was born November 17, 1910, in Fleming County,
Kentucky. He obtained the A.B.
degree from Transylvania College in Lexington and his M.A.
in Classics from the University
of Kentucky.
After serving as a special agent
with the U. S. Army CounterIntelligence Corps during the
war, he pursued graduate studies
at Hopkins until 1950 when he
received a Ph.D. in Education.
Dr. Walton has been the director
of MAT since its conception and
chairman of the Department of
Education since 1960. Last summer he was on the faculty as
a
visiting professor with the
University of California at Santa
Bailpara.
Author

numerous articles and several
books on the subject of education. His books include John Filson of Kentucky, Administrati
on
and Policy-Making in Educat
ion,
and Toward Better Teachi
ng in

which is
now in the process of
being published. He also contributes to
the
Harvard Educational Review
and
co-edited The Discipline
of Edn•
cation.

on

ng for

Drop Date
We view with alarm the callous decision of the
Committee on Undergraduate Standing to move the drop
date a full six weeks forward on the semester calendar.
In doing so, the Administration displays an appalling lack of sympathy and a desperate misunderstanding
of what it means to attend this University as an Undergraduate.
We as Undergraduates are aware that our University functions primarily as a Graduate institution. We
will not dispute the obvious fact that a large measure of
what makes the Undergraduate school unique is the attitudes that are transmitted from the Graduate division.
Nevertheless, it is vital that the Administration
make some distinctions between its student bodies. At
the most basic level, the Administration must realize
that most concerns to which Undergraduates direct themselves are extra-academic. Therefore it is imperative
ihat we balance academic efficiency with the maintenance
of a psychological climate conducive to learning.
It is axiomatic that any University offer its students
flexibility. Before effecting the current system, Hopkins
not only offered flexibility but a system of options whereby a student was permitted to "give up" without incurring punishment. He was permitted to experience
tacit rather than actual failure and thus was permitted
to learn something from the experience.
"Nothing," Bob Dylan once said "succeeds like
failure." It is important that the Administration realize
that it is dealing with people. People only fail when
they are trapped without the opportunity to change their
minds. Failure only leads to failure. If it is the Administration's intention to reduce the size of the Undergraduate student body, then it has undertaken a masterful plan.
But if it believes that we, as prospective real people,
stand to learn as much from failure as success, it will
reverse its present policy before it does irreparable harm
to even one student.

Fraternities Rushed
While the News-Letter hardly sympathizes with
George P. Mahoney's contention that "A man's home is
his castle," we nevertheless are becoming convinced that
a Hopkins man's apartment or fraternity house, if located southeast of the campus, must, of necessity, be a
fortress.
For years now, it has been the summer pastime
for neighborhood toughs to ransack and loot fraternity
houses, with little recource available to the agrieved
brothers. During the school year, the local billies have
similarly shown little reluctance to enter the residences
of Hopkins students, peacefully or otherwise.
Last year, a gang invaded the apartment of four
Hopkins men near 27th and St. Paul Streets, and were
repelled only when confronted with a shotgun. The knifewielding incident at 29th and Calvert last Friday night
is another case in point. And during the rush season,
every fraternity house at one time or another is visited
by local youths who inevitably get drunk and obstinately
refuse to leave quietly.
The University administration, although intensely
mindful of retaining a favorable Hopkins public image,
has still gone to considerable lengths to give fraternities
and individuals the freedom they so greatly desire, especially in the matter of drinking. It has attempted, with
occasional success, to have the Baltimore police adopt
this outlook, also. Having encouraged the local constabulary to look the other way in one matter, the fraternities now register their anger and amazement when
the police hesitate to exert themselves to the utmost to
curtail the activities of the neighborhood juvenile delinquents.
The problem is compounded by the city's notorious lack of police personnel, the inability of the average
Baltimore cop to recognize that two wrongs don't make
a right, and the fact that the many Hopkins people not
in fraternities, but residing in the area, are victims of
an antagonistic police attiude of whose creation they had
no part.
We hope that, when the I.F.C. president meets
with a representative of the Baltimore police next week,
these problems will be frankly discussed and that some
adequate solution can be achieved.

must remember the difficulties
faced by an administration that
must please diverse elements in
our society. Yet there are points
when petty disadvantages turn
into grievous and harmful problems, When this point is reached, it is the duty of the members
of the community to unite in an
effort to alleviate the burden
placed upon them. I firmly believe that the problem and
burden which confront both our
sense of justice and our pocketbooks, the inadequacy of the
Johns Hopkins Bookstore, must
now be faced in this spirit.
Every person connected academically with our university is
personally touched by this problem. In my mind it is twofold:
first, there is an inadequacy in
space, service, and atmosphere
which Makes it distasteful to
even enter the bookstore; and
secondly, there is an exorbitant
profit made on each and every
book and off of each and every
purchaser.
We have been told that the
crowded conditions will be alleviated when the renovation of
Gilman Hall is complete (although one professor makes the
point that\he hardly sees where
the bookstore will have room to
expand what with all they plan
to put in the building). Yet this
is but a partial solution. Will we
still have to stand in line for
forty minutes only to find that
the essential book has not arrived? Will we still have to
search painfully for an object
that is hidden in some obscure
corner? What atmosphere will
be present? Perhaps the answers
to some of these questions could
be found in a summer mailing of
booklists so that students could
buy elsewhere or bring books from

home, in a lounging area where
purchasers could sit and browse,
in self-service shelves for textbooks, or in the selling of cultural objects such as prints and.
records.
If these "aesthetic" issues
seem essential, think for a moment about the economic concerns. A rumor (supposedly SUb—
stantiated by the report of the
Long Range Planning Committee) claims that the bookstore's
yearly profit can be approximated at $25,000 which is then
supposedly directed to some obscure or abstract use which helps
the student body. It would seem
to me that some explanation on
the part of the administration is
required. But also something
further. Why cannot our bookstore be run with our economic
comfort in mind? Why must we
pay list prices and receive inadequate service while students
at other top universities (undet.
a co-operative or discount program) pay decidedly less?
I believe that these questions
can be answered this year, but
it will take a united and concerted effort on the part of the
undergraduates, the graduates,
the evening students, and the
faculty. If their efforts be chanthrough a dedicated
nelled
Student Council. I believe we
will find success. And this success will be only the beginning.
Soon the administration will
learn that we speak with a constructive and responsible voice,
and then our other desires will
be acted upon—improved food, a
Student Union, etc. It is now
that we must act—to make the
bookstore an instrument of
academic pursuit and not one of
economic chicanery.
David M. Punk

Students Recruited
At present Hopkins is rather
unique in its teaching degree
system; there are only about
twenty other schools in the
country that offer such instruction, among them Brown, U. of
Chicago, and Duke.
The MAT students come from
colleges located in every section
of the country. As a result of an
efficient publicity campaign, Dr.
Walton states that his office receives around 500 completed applications per year and' thousands of inquiries. "We try to
get a geographical spread," he
maintains. Fewer than 10% of
the MAT's come from Balitmore,
while over 25% remain here to
teach. In this sense Dr. Walton
feels that his department makes
a definite contribution to the
local community.

Mansfield, Weaver
To Lecture Hopkins
By DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN
Robert C. Weaver, Secretary
of Housing and Redevelopment
will give the Albert and Gloria
Lion Lecture on Sunday, October
23, at 4 p.m. in Shriver Hall.

Rudolph Serkin, one of the
vvorld's most eminent pianists,
Will perform in Shriver Hall this
Sunday night at 8:30 p.m. with
violinist Pina Carmirelli. The
two will play the Beethoven
Piano and violin sonatas.
Educated under Arnold
Schoenberg, Rudolf Serkin has
been recognized as one of the
world's finest Beethoven interMeters. As both founder and director of the Marlboro Music
School, to which the proceeds
from this Sunday's concert will
go, he has marked himself as one
of the most generous of contemporary artists. His great contribution to America's cultural life
was recognized in 1963 when
President Kennedy awarded him
the Medal for Freedom.

covered the good Dean's desk, bookcases, light fixture, and children — small Paul on the left and David on the right. The pranksters entered through a window and proceeded to cut gas in
the late Sunday night hours. It was not known whether the act
had some hidden symbolism pertaining to the Dean's fetishes.

Audiences must realize, for instance, that art is not life.
Though it may closely resemble
it, there are still certain conventions in art which must be

from The Umbrellas of Cherbourg where the scenery moves
behind the boy and girl who are
singing a love duet and are obviously not walking. The viewer's
concentration should naturally
be on the couple held in our

express their love and anguish.
The moving scenery, caught by
peripheral vision, should give the
illusion of their motion in space.

Fan Fare

(Continued trom Page 10)

By STEVE PUTNAMIt was a clutch pass that gained the Jays a tie last Saturday,
but to the fans in the rain it
seemed like a victory. Such was
the just reward received by our
hard-core rooters who survived
the afternoon's downpour. Certainly the Jay football team can
not claim as many fans as the
Metz, but in quality and persistence, our fan is comparable
if not superior.
It had to be one of the more
thrilling moments in the history
of Homewood Field, as Phil Parthmore directed a sensational
last minute drive to stave off
defeat. For the Jays it was the
first time in iive years that they
did not lose an opener, and as
for F&M—they went back home
wondering about the remaining
season.
Ursinus Upset
Tomorrow we take on a tough
Ursinus ball club which also tied
last week, playing a scoreless
game with Muhlenburg. Ursinus
IS considered tough because they
have nineteen returning lettermen, including all of their eleven
offensive starters. Last year this
same basic team beat F&M 35-

13. The Jays' line will be outweighed on the average by fifteen pounds per man, but again
there is not complete cause for
despair. No serious injuries were
sustained last week by our magic
"double dozen," and hopefully
with a little luck and support
the team can pull an upset.
Directions
Question three of course is —
who and where is Ursinus? Take
95 north of Maryland State, and
exit at Wilmington, Delaware.
Pick up route 202 and go up to
route 29 around West Chester.
Battle along through construction until you see signs to Collegeville. (Don't be alarmed if
the Pennsylvania
border is
crossed). The Ursinus campus is
located just north of this quaint
Pennsylvania town.
After the game, you might
want to stop at the famous
Smorgasbord restaurant in Collegeville where three dollars
gains you access to all you can
eat. In any event, the Jays need
all the fans they can get for this
tough battle. If they win this
game the prospect of going undefeated becomes almost conceivable.

30 Frosh Gridders
Kick Off Practice
By JEFF LAUREN
The freshmen football team
opened practice last week with
thirty men on Coach Bob Scott's
roster.
Since the young Blue- Jays
have worked out for such a short
time, Scott hesitated to make a
forecast for the '66 season. Only
about half the team has experi.ence.
The team as a whole does not
have the strength or experience
Of the last few Hopkin's frosh
teams. The combined record for
the past two years for freshmen
football is 6-1. It will be an extremely difficult task for this
Year's group to do as well, but
Scott feels that they have the
Potential to offer a good, representative showing.
The coach and his staff will
have a better idea of their team's
strengths and weaknesses when
Harford Junior College comes to
Homewood this Friday afternoon.
Even though Harford has played
a game already and Hopkins has
Only been in pads for a week, the
scrimage will give the coaches
and players a basis from which
to work.
